titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Century of Progress International Exposition - New York World's Fair Collection
World's Fair (Century of Progress International Exposition - New York) Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by Susan Grigg

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday January 4, 2019 at 08:25

did.unittitle: Century of Progress International Exposition - New York World's Fair collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The collection includes printed matter and publicity material related to the Century of Progress International Exposition in Chicago (1933-1934) and the New York World's Fair (1939-1940), including such miscellaneous administrative records of the New York World's Fair as the annual report for 1938 and organizational charts. A main strength of the collection is the printed material from more than one thousand exhibitors at both fairs, comprising business, non-profit institutions, and governments. The manufacturers' catalogues in many cases offer lists of specifications and illustrations of both capital and consumer goods, which also provide a broad sampling of advertising and design of the period.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Century of Progress International Exposition - New York World's Fair Collection (MS 820). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: These items were brought together by Yale Librarian Sherman Kent, who solicited most of them from the exhibitors. Much of the administrative material for the New York World's Fair was contributed by its Director of Research, Frank Monaghan, also an assistant professor of history at Yale.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series: I. Century of Progress. II. New York World's Fair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Century of Progress International Exposition - New York World's Fair Collection consists of forty-one linear feet of printed matter and publicity material related to the exhibits at the Century of Progress International Exposition in Chicago (1933-1934) and the New York World's Fair (1939-1940). These items were brought together by Yale Librarian Sherman Kent, who solicited most of them by mail from the exhibitors. He received not only material prepared for distribution at the fairs, but also other current publications, some of which were not available to visitors at the exhibits. From the fair administrations he obtained guidebooks, newspapers, press releases, photographs, and other publicity and administrative material. Much of the administrative material for the New York World's Fair was contributed by its Director of Research, Frank Monaghan, who was also an assistant professor of history at Yale.

Many exhibitors do not appear in the collection because they did not respond to the Library's request or did not have anything to send, but the thousand or more exhibitors who are included are broadly representative of the two expositions. Most belong to one of three categories: businesses, non-profit institutions, and governments. Among the businesses are such major corporations as General Motors and Republic Steel and such smaller firms as the Coatesville Plate Washer Company and American Bird Products, Inc. The non-profit institutions include schools (Tri-State College), charities (The American Committee for the Control of Rheumatism), and churches (the Seventh-Day Adventists). Among the governments are those of American states and of many countries in Europe and Latin America, although the beginning of the Second World War led to the cancellation of some foreign exhibits in 1940. There is a separate series for each exposition, and each series is arranged alphabetically by exhibitor.

The contents of the exhibitors' publications can be summarized under three headings: explanation of the exhibit; description of the exhibitor's product or service; and general information related to the product or service. The nature of the material in the first category is self-evident. The second category has some items prepared for distribution at the fairs but consists mainly of catalogs and brochures intended for general use in public or customer relations. The third category is exemplified by a booklet, Cleanliness through the Ages, offered by the Cudahy Packing Company, distributor of Old Dutch Cleanser.

This collection is a valuable source of information about the expositions, the exhibits, and the ordinary activities of individual exhibitors. Especially important from the latter point of view are the catalogs and brochures of manufacturers, which provide lists, specifications, and illustrations of such capital and consumer goods as industrial machinery, automobiles, and furniture. The representation of activities other than manufacturing is less comprehensive but still useful. Researchers seeking specific information about exhibits or exhibitors will find it helpful to consult the index boxed at the beginning of each series, which lists both exhibitors and their major products.

The collection is also an important resource for the study of American society and, culture in the 1930s, whether the historian chooses to address the subject directly or to use either fair to epitomize certain themes. The Century of Progress International Exposition and the New York World's Fair were showcases for American institutions, and the publications in this collection offer massive evidence of their ideas about their nation and their time. Historians undertaking this kind of study may want to orient themselves by examining the guidebooks and other general material boxed at the beginning of each series or by consulting the Chicago Tribune and the New York Timeson microfilm.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

controlaccess.corpname: Century of Progress International Exposition ( 1933-1934 Chicago, Ill.)
New York World's Fair ( 1939-1940 New York, N.Y.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Boxes 1 and lA contain an index to the exhibitors represented in this series with some cross-references from product to exhibitor. It is not guaranteed to be entirely accurate or complete.
Boxes 2-4 contain general publications and miscellaneous publicity and administrative material.
Boxes 4-34 contain publications, printed novelty items, and photographs related to individual exhibits. The arrangement is alphabetical by exhibitor.
Boxes 35 and 35A contain oversize publications related to individual exhibits.

Harold H. Laskey: lists of publications about Chicago and the Century of Progress, 1933-1934
Programs for days in honor of foreign countries
World's Fair Clip Sheet (for use by newspaper editors), 1934 Mar 12 - Oct 8
United States D - United States M

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Boxes 36A-D contain an index to the exhibitors represented in this series with some cross-references from product to exhibitor. They are not guaranteed to be entirely accurate or complete.
Boxes 36-40 contain general publications and miscellaneous publicity and administrative material.

Boxes 40-86 contain publications, printed novelty items, and photographs related to individual exhibits. The arrangement is alphabetical by exhibitor except that Boxes 83-86 contain miscellaneous and oversize items.
